title: Evaluating Precise Geolocation Inference Capabilities of Vision Language Models
author: Neel Jay (Apart Research), Hieu Minh "Jord" Nguyen (Apart Research), Trung Dung Hoang (Hanoi University of Science and Technology), Jacob Haimes (Apart Research)
relevance_why: The methodologies for geolocation inference and visual reasoning in this work could inspire new approaches for integrating audio and visual data in speech and sound processing tasks.
background: This paper focuses on using Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to accurately infer geographic locations from images, analyzing the effectiveness of these models on a diverse dataset.
contribution: This paper introduces a benchmark dataset and evaluates the geolocation capabilities of foundation Vision-Language Models, achieving median distance errors of less than 300 km.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous studies primarily focused on country classification without precise geolocation and did not leverage VLMs’ full capabilities for image reasoning.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work effectively benchmarks single-image geolocation and includes the use of VLM agents with additional tools, showing performance improvements.

key_innovation: Demonstrates that foundation models, with limited tool access, can achieve competitive geolocation accuracy without specific training for this task.
real_world_impact: Addresses significant privacy concerns with the geolocation capabilities of VLMs, indicating potential risks when these models are used in real-world applications.
limitations: The dataset lacks comprehensive representation from some regions, such as Russia and Africa, which might bias the findings.

new_terms.Vision-Language Models (VLMs): **Vision-Language Models** are AI models that can process and understand information from both visual (images, video) and textual data.
new_terms.median distance error: **Median distance error** is a statistical measure that identifies the middle value in the distance errors when predicting location based on input images.

open_sourcing: Datasets and code can be found at: https://github.com/njspyx/location-inference
